predictions.text: U.S. Treasury (OFAC) will publish a new or amended Venezuela-related General License that explicitly authorizes (expands) oil and/or gas sector transactions with Venezuelan state-linked entities (e.g., PDVSA) by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if OFAC posts on its website a new or amended Venezuela GL (or GL FAQ update explicitly tied to a GL) that expands authorization for oil/gas transactions versus the then-current baseline, and the text explicitly references Venezuela and oil/gas sector activity.
monitoring_signals: OFAC ‘Recent Actions’ page for Venezuela-related updates
U.S. State Department press briefings on Venezuela negotiations
Major oil-company statements (Chevron/Eni/Repsol) about license terms
predictions.rationale: Venezuela’s political move to court U.S. support increases the likelihood of incremental sanctions relief aimed at oil flows, especially if tied to electoral or humanitarian conditions.

predictions.text: The Nikkei 225 index will record at least one daily close at or above 45,000 by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if the official Nikkei 225 closing value (as published by Nikkei/major market data providers) is ≥ 45,000 on any trading day on or before the deadline.
monitoring_signals: JPY/USD trend and BoJ policy communications
Japan fiscal-policy announcements consistent with pro-growth agenda
Foreign inflow data into Japanese equities (weekly/monthly flow reports)
predictions.rationale: A strong political mandate can reinforce risk-on positioning and earnings optimism, but the 45k threshold requires sustained momentum and supportive FX/macro conditions.

predictions.text: Thailand’s government will declare a state of emergency (or equivalent emergency decree) covering Bangkok due to post-election unrest by 2026-05-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if Thailand’s Royal Gazette or an official government announcement confirms a state of emergency/emergency decree that explicitly includes Bangkok and cites public disorder/protests as the reason.
monitoring_signals: Public protest size/frequency reported by major wire services
Statements from Thai police/military about crowd-control escalation
Royal Gazette postings of emergency decrees
predictions.rationale: Surprise political outcomes raise protest risk, but emergency declarations are a high bar and depend on escalation beyond routine demonstrations.

predictions.text: The U.S. CFTC will issue a formal public action (order, settlement, no-action letter withdrawal, or rulemaking notice) that explicitly addresses sports-event prediction markets/contracts (not just elections) by 2026-04-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if the CFTC posts on cftc.gov a document (Federal Register notice, Commission order, settlement, staff letter, or enforcement release) that explicitly references sports-event contracts/markets and sets policy, restrictions, or enforcement posture toward them.
monitoring_signals: CFTC ‘Press Releases’ and ‘Federal Register Notices’ pages
Major prediction-market operator announcements on sports contracts
State AG/public gaming regulator statements complaining about event contracts
predictions.rationale: Regulatory pressure is rising as sports-event contracts blur gambling/derivatives lines; the CFTC is a focal point for clarifying permissibility.

predictions.text: The CFPB will publish a consumer advisory, circular, supervisory highlight, or enforcement action explicitly focused on generative-AI-driven financial advice (including retirement planning) by 2026-09-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if the CFPB posts an official publication or enforcement release that explicitly mentions generative AI/LLMs/chatbots used to provide financial advice (including retirement planning) and frames it as a consumer-protection or compliance issue.
monitoring_signals: CFPB newsroom and guidance/circulars page updates
CFPB speeches mentioning AI in consumer finance
High-profile incidents of chatbot financial-advice harm or mis-selling claims
predictions.rationale: Growing consumer use plus liability/bias concerns make regulatory communication plausible, but CFPB prioritization versus other issues is uncertain.

predictions.text: Microsoft will publish a security advisory and ship Windows security updates that explicitly mitigate a bypass of UEFI Secure Boot involving signed bootloaders, with at least one associated CVE, by 2026-03-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if Microsoft’s MSRC posts an advisory referencing UEFI Secure Boot bypass via signed bootloaders and Patch Tuesday (or out-of-band) release notes list one or more CVEs with a fix/mitigation tied to that issue by the deadline.
monitoring_signals: MSRC ‘Security Update Guide’ entries mentioning Secure Boot/UEFI
New CVEs referencing bootloader/DBX revocation
OEM advisories (Dell/HP/Lenovo) about Secure Boot mitigation steps
predictions.rationale: Secure Boot bypasses via signed components are typically addressed through advisories plus revocation/patch mechanisms once validated.

predictions.text: The U.S. State Department will impose a new public visa restriction or sanction measure targeting at least one Hong Kong or PRC official, explicitly citing the Jimmy Lai sentencing or Hong Kong political prosecutions, by 2026-12-31 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if the State Department (or Treasury) publishes a press statement or designation notice naming at least one individual and explicitly linking the action to Jimmy Lai’s sentencing/prosecution or Hong Kong political prosecutions (e.g., under HK Autonomy Act/Magnitsky/visa restriction authorities).
monitoring_signals: State Department press releases on Hong Kong/China actions
Congressional letters urging sanctions post-sentencing
Allied statements (UK/EU/Canada) coordinating responses
predictions.rationale: High-profile sentencing can trigger targeted measures, but escalation competes with broader U.S.-China priorities and may be calibrated to avoid retaliation.

predictions.text: A U.S. House standing committee will hold a public hearing that explicitly discusses conflicts-of-interest or governance concerns related to U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, referencing the Epstein records reporting, by 2026-06-30 (UTC).
predictions.verification_criteria: Resolves Yes if a House committee publishes an official hearing notice/memo and the hearing record (title, witness statements, or opening remarks) explicitly references Lutnick and Epstein records/files/reporting as part of the hearing’s subject matter.
monitoring_signals: House Oversight, Ways & Means, and Energy & Commerce hearing calendars
Public committee letters requesting documents from Commerce
Inspector General announcements touching Commerce leadership issues
predictions.rationale: Media-driven governance controversies sometimes prompt hearings, but scheduling and partisan bandwidth make this uncertain without new disclosures.
